## In-Person Connection Practice: Art 

**Date:** Monday, December 29, 2025 at 6:30 PM

**Location:** SeekHealing, 50 S French Broad Ave #300, Asheville, NC

**Organizer:** SeekHealing Asheville

**Price:** Free

**Source:** MEETUP

**Tags:** Art, Wellness, Community, Spiritual, Support Groups

**Score:** 5/30 (Rarity: 1, Unique: 2, Magnitude: 2)
**Score Reason:** Weekly recurring event - happens every week.

**AI Summary:** Practicing deep listening and nonjudgmental connection through collaborative expressive art, with a strict no-advice rule.

### Description

You will be provided with your sanitized supplies, or feel free to bring your own colored pencils, markers, or other art supplies to express yourself during this Connection Practice Meeting.

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates. All connection practices are free of charge.

### Description

Shut Up & Write!

**Here's how it works.** Show up at or before 6:00. At 6:00, we do some quick introductions. Afterward, for a full 60 minutes (I'll set a timer!) we are heads-down writing. Writing what? A novel? You bet. Some poetry? Sure. Song lyrics? Your resume? That report you need to get to your boss before 8 AM or you'll *need* *to write* that resume? All of the above and more. Just shut up and write.

Surrounding ourselves with other writers who are busy putting words onto page (physical or virtual) keeps us all accountable and focused.

When the timer goes off, we'll check-in with each other and see how it went. Afterward, feel free to stay to chat and get to know your fellow writers, or keep writing, or take off.

Socializing is optional and will happen after (or briefly before) the focused writing. This is a safe space to work on your craft. No one will read or critique your writing.

For more information about our events, visit [https://shutupwrite.com](https://shutupwrite.com).

**What to Expect**

* Roughly 15 minutes of introductions
* 60 minutes of focused writing (somebody set a timer)!
* Afterward, optional socializing

**Being late is okay:** Just show up and get settled, then check in with the host after the session. (Look for the person with the Shut Up & Write sign).

**What Should I Bring?**

* Whatever you need to be able to write!
* Earbuds/earplugs if you want to block ambient noise.

**Other Important Details:**

HOSTS: This is a multi-host event, so most of the time there will be a host present. If we are unlucky and no host can attend, please find each other and self-organize. Pay attention to the event chat and comments to see who is available.

WI-FI: Yes!

PARKING: Street parking in metered spots is free after 6pm. Closest municipal garages ($2/hour) are Wall St. & Coxe Street/Sears Alley.

### Description

Registration opens Sunday, Dec 28, at 5 PM.

This is a lovely patch of Bent Creek. We'll have views toward Sleepy Gap Overlook and Chestnut Cove Overlook from afar as well as toward Grassy Knob, Tuckwheel Mountain, Pine Mountain, and Cold Mountain as shown above from the perspective of Lower Sidehill Trail. Then we'll cross over onto the other side of the hollar and hike South Ridge Road. Then its down through the cove forest known as Chestnut to the Explorer Loop parking lot, with a return on a portion of Lower Sidehill to complete the lollipop.

**Parking choices:**
**1) Car pool:** I will be at the Outlet Mall behind behind the Waffle House. Look for the 2000 Toyota Tacoma pickup truck. Car pool **leaves at 9:30 A.M.** with whoever is there at that time.
**2) Trailhead:** Meet at the trailhead, which has a tiny lot. **Consider the carpool option**. The trailhead is at the intersection of Bent Creek Gap Road and Forest Service Road 479F (Boyd Branch Road), which is 1 mile beyond Ledford Branch Parking lot. This 1 mile segment is a dirt road. Parking is in a small lot and along the shoulder. **The map shows the trailhead parking.**

**Stats:**
Distance: approx. 6.5 miles
Pace: 2 mph to 2.5 mph
Ascent: approx. 1,000 feet

**Price:** Free

**Score:** 5/30 (Rarity: 1, Unique: 2, Magnitude: 2)
**Score Reason:** Weekly recurring event - happens every week.

**AI Summary:** Cultivating deep, nonjudgmental listening through facilitated exercises and a strict no-advice practice for genuine connection.

### Description

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates.

-Open, safe space for sharing and self-care for Black people

**AI Summary:** Featuring 7 km and 10 km paved route options through the urban trail, with hills, stairs, and dog-friendly pacing.

### Description

We are joining the Asheville Amblers Walking Club, Stryder, AARP, and perhaps some others, for this walk. Dress for the weather.

There are some hills and stairs, but this walk is nearly all on pavement. Tennis shoes are fine, but some may want walking sticks. This walk would not be good for wheelchairs and would be rather difficult for strollers. Dogs on leash would be ok.

As always, bring water and a protein snack.

Enjoy portions of the Urban Trail through the vibrant art deco downtown and the ambience of a designated "All American City". Visit the Grove Arcade with shops and restaurants to depict its original uniqueness as an indoor shopping mall back in the 1920s. Walk by the Thomas Wolfe Home, well known author of *Look Homeward, Angel* and *You Can't Go Home Again*. Visit several old neighborhoods of Asheville and the Greenway along Reed Creek. Meander through the historic Montford District with old homes and B&Bs. Ramble through Riverside Cemetery where O. Henry (author of "The Gift of the Magi") and Thomas Wolfe are buried.

We will register at 12:30 in the parking lot behind the Asheville Chamber of Commerce Visitors Center. The Visitors Center will be closed, so we suggest taking care of any personal needs just prior to arrival.

The walk is free, although donations to the Amblers would be accepted ($4 suggested). Step-off will be at 1:00. Choose between a 7 KM/4 mile and a 10 KM/6 mile version of the walk. The walk will be guided by experienced group walking leaders.

**AI Summary:** Featuring a nearly flat, 7.2-mile out-and-back hike along creek rapids to the French Broad confluence.

### Description

**Sign-up opens Sunday, December 28th, at 8:00 PM.**

***HAPPY 2026!***

This out-and-back hike northwest of Asheville is a spectacular stroll along the picturesque Big Laurel Creek. You'll see many beautiful views of the creek's rapids, pools, and gorges along the way.

We'll take the trail all the way to its terminus at the confluence of Big Laurel Creek and the French Broad River. There, we'll pause for around a 15-minute break before heading back.

The trail is nearly flat, but rather stony and rooted in places. Hiking poles are advisable if you might feel unsteady. There are around a half-dozen trivial stream crossings, and there may be some muddy spots here and there along the route.

We'll do a steady 2.3-ish mph pace. I'd put the difficulty level at 3/10.

Well-behaved dogs are welcome on-leash. Wear sensible hiking boots. Bring some water and a snack or lunch if you'd like.

**CARPOOLING TIME & PLACE**

We'll carpool from the **Weaverville Publix Supermarket** and leave there at **9:30 AM** sharp, so *come a few minutes early*. It's at **165 Weaver Blvd.**, Weaverville. **Exit 19B from I-26.** We'll gather at the **west end of the lot**, which is to the left as you face the store. (Look for me and my silver Hyundai sedan.) It'll be a 25-minute drive to the trailhead. We'll be back at Publix by roughly 1:30 PM.

**[Weaverville Publix on Google Maps](https://goo.gl/maps/Dw3KEb5oZP2dSVBR7)**
https://goo.gl/maps/Dw3KEb5oZP2dSVBR7

If you plan to meet us at the trailhead, please post a comment or message me, and arrive by 10:00. The parking lot is at "Big Laurel Trailhead" on Rt. 25/70 just before it turns into Rt. 208.

**[Trailhead parking lot on Google maps](https://goo.gl/maps/R9zYZpTPfEHAjoB58)**
https://goo.gl/maps/R9zYZpTPfEHAjoB58

**COURTESY TO WAITLISTERS (Please abide!)**

### Description

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates.

## Walk Biltmore Estate's Deer Park Trail on National Chocolate Covered Cherry Day

**Date:** Saturday, January 3, 2026 at 12:00 PM

**Location:** Biltmore, 1 Lodge St, Asheville, NC

**Organizer:** Haywood County Walking Meetup Group

**Price:** Free

**Source:** MEETUP

**Tags:** Outdoors, Community, biltmore, deer park trail, nature walk, walking meetup, scenic

**Score:** 11/30 (Rarity: 3, Unique: 5, Magnitude: 3)
**Score Reason:** A free, beginner-friendly group walk on the scenic Biltmore Deer Park Trail ‚Äî pleasant and slightly more special because of the Biltmore setting and the holiday tie-in, but it's a routine meetup-style walk (common recurring format) with a local/community draw rather than a major headliner.

**AI Summary:** Exploring scenic Deer Park and Garden trails on a beginner-friendly group walk with route guidance and organizer support.

### Description

Travel past the Biltmore House toward Antler Hill Village. Park in the first available area just past the Lagoon. We will access the Deer Park Trail from there. (I will be monitoring the Comments section of this walk page and also Meetup messages. If you get confused or lost, contact me right away.)

Deer Park Trail goes through the Deer Park (though it isn't near Lioncrest and the other DeerPark facilities). It comes to a T intersection. We will go right to where you can access the Garden Trails. Then we will turn around and go up the hill to the South Terrace of the Biltmore House. From there we will retrace our steps to the start point. It is about 2.5 miles round trip, or so says the map.

I've done this walk in both tennis shoes and in light hiking boots (from a different start point). I'll probably bring walking poles for the hill, though most of the walk won't need them.

Bring plenty of water and a protein snack. Dress for the weather; consider a hat and sunscreen. Dogs are welcome. Trail strollers would probably work.

PS: It being National Chocolate Covered Cherry Day, we just might enjoy a box of cherries at the end of the walk!!

### Description

With the new year upon us, it is time for the Surreal Sirkus to return to our roots: indeed to the roots of surrealism itself. 

While the spectacle and theatrics of the big productions is how we draw the audience into our world, it is in the small interactions between ourselves that that world is created: the brainstorming sessions, the potluck... the salon. 

This was true for the OG surrealists, who would gather at the apartment of Andr√© and Simone Breton in Paris in the 1920s to discuss art, philosophy, and politics, share creative ideas, and play surrealist games ‚Äî exercises in creating art by accessing the unconscious mind. 

Surreal Sirkus invites you to come take part in a similar salon, as we start to dream the next chapters of our collective story. 

If you feel so called, bring a song or a story or a poem or performance to share. At the very least be prepared to participate in some games. And of course, bring your imagination!

And bring a beverage or snack to share. 

Donations are not required, but are welcome to help support the space.

### Description

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates.

**There are moments in our lives, there are moments in a day, when we seem to see beyond the usual--become clairvoyant. We reach then into reality. Such are the moments of our greatest happiness. Such are the moments of our greatest vision....At such times there is a song going on within us, a song to which we listen. It fills us with surprise. We marvel at it. We would continue to hear it. But few are capable of holding themselves in the state of listening to their song. Intellectuality steps in and as the song within us is of the utmost sensitiveness, it retires in the presence of the cold, material intellect. It is aristocratic and will not associate itself with the commonplace--and we fall back and become our ordinary selves. Yet we live in the memory of these songs which in moments of intellectual inadvertence have been possible to us. They are the pinnacles of our experience and it is the desire to express these intimate sensations, this song from within, which motivates the masters of all art.**
**\- Robert Henri from The Art**

**AI Summary:** Offering introvert-friendly silent reading for fantasy and sci-fi fans in a relaxed, beer-friendly back-room setting.

### Description

BOYB - Bring Your Own Book and spill the beer (literally and metaphorically) on your current favorite Fantasy and Sci-fi titles at Day Trip! We will likely be in the large ‚Äòback room‚Äô (with the Disco Ball)

**What is a Silent Book Club?**
Referred to as "Introvert's Happy Hour", Silent Book clubs allow readers to engage with each other without the commitment of reading a shared title. Community members gather in the same place, have some casual chit chat, and then read silently together. **This group will focus on Fantasy and Sci-Fi titles (subgenres & related genres are welcome!)**

**How does it work?**
For the first 15-30 mins we will gather, grab our food and drink and engage in introductions. Feel free to discuss your recent favorites, mention a title that lives in your head rent free, or ask for recommendations! The best part of the Silent Book Club is being able to talk shop with other readers!

Once settled in we will dedicate 45 minutes to silent reading. Your book can be traditional, ebook, or audiobook. Read at your own pace!

Afterwards we will go around show-and-tell style and share what we read with the group. We want to know what you're reading! Organic dialogue welcome!

### Description

The Core represents everything essential about Asheville's jazz DNA distilled into five musicians who understand that the best ensembles aren't just collections of individual talents-they're alchemical reactions where individual voices merge into something greater than their sum. This quintet embodies the mountain city's unique musical ecosystem, where Blue Ridge authenticity meets sophisticated harmonic exploration, where the intimacy of local venues allows for the kind of musical risk-taking that transforms standards into personal statements. Named for their ability to get to the heart of every song they touch, The Core strips away musical pretense to reveal the emotional architecture beneath, proving that jazz at its best isn't about showing off-it's about showing up completely for each moment, each phrase, each possibility that emerges when five musicians breathe together in perfect musical democracy. In Asheville's thriving jazz scene, The Core stands as both inheritors of tradition and pioneers of what's next, reminding audiences that the most profound musical experiences happen when virtuosity serves vulnerability, when technique becomes the vehicle for something infinitely more human.

### Description

You will be provided with your sanitized supplies, or feel free to bring your own colored pencils, markers, or other art supplies to express yourself during this Connection Practice Meeting.

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates. All connection practices are free of charge.

Shut Up & Write!

**Here's how it works.** Show up at or before 6:00. At 6:00, we do some quick introductions. Afterward, for a full 60 minutes (I'll set a timer!) we are heads-down writing. Writing what? A novel? You bet. Some poetry? Sure. Song lyrics? Your resume? That report you need to get to your boss before 8 AM or you'll *need* *to write* that resume? All of the above and more. Just shut up and write.

Surrounding ourselves with other writers who are busy putting words onto page (physical or virtual) keeps us all accountable and focused.

When the timer goes off, we'll check-in with each other and see how it went. Afterward, feel free to stay to chat and get to know your fellow writers, or keep writing, or take off.

Socializing is optional and will happen after (or briefly before) the focused writing. This is a safe space to work on your craft. No one will read or critique your writing.

* Roughly 15 minutes of introductions
* 60 minutes of focused writing (somebody set a timer)!
* Afterward, optional socializing

**What Should I Bring?**

* Whatever you need to be able to write!
* Earbuds/earplugs if you want to block ambient noise.

**Other Important Details:**

HOSTS: This is a multi-host event, so most of the time there will be a host present. If we are unlucky and no host can attend, please find each other and self-organize. Pay attention to the event chat and comments to see who is available.

### Description

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates.

We are here to facilitate your journey of trauma-relief and stress-management.

And it can be done in just a few minutes using nothing but your own breath...

Over the last 10 years, we've taught over 100,000 people to do just that.
The key is that your breath is directly linked to your emotions.

-Open, safe space for sharing and self-care for Black people
-Facilitated discussion
-Breath work and meditation

Led by Black facilitators, certified in stress and trauma relief.
Unleash the Hidden Healing Power of the Breath

### Description

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates.

### Description

PJ Bond PJ Bond is a wandering songster who has traversed the American and European landscapes more times than he can easily count. He got his start over ten years ago in what was then called the DIY Indie scene, back when musicians still made money on CDs and people spent a lot of their time trying to get signed. A decade later, Bond‚Äôs lyrically dark but otherwise upbeat songs span from introspective Americana to reverb-laden rock from an earlier era. If forced to draw parallels and speak of influences, one might say he has drawn from the likes of Elliott Smith and Wilco, though he might prefer to credit Bruce Springsteen and Bob Dylan these days. When not traveling the globe, PJ currently lives in Asheville, NC, listening to country music, and making pizza. Sufferin' Fools The fine fellows in Sufferin' Fools congregate around the mountain made tunes of Cameron Thomas. Born and bred in the Carolinas, Thomas' songs share the humble joys, struggles and mysteries of a southern life - where it might lead you, who you meet, and what you bring back home. The band rides the dusty crossroads of Memphis country soul and Midwest power pop - kicking the dual guitars into overdrive for fun. The band's second EP, Forest for the Trees, was released on 9/26/25 and is available on all streaming platforms. Garden Apartments West Asheville trio, Garden Apartments, blend the best elements of Americana, Psych and 90's Indie Rock to create a unique but familiar sound. Tight and minimal arrangements provide the backdrop to Rustin Bragaw's immediately captivating voice, accompanied by the tasteful guitar work of Chris Pearson and the solid drumming of Daniel Hawkins. Each player brings years of recording and touring experience to the table. The trio has been playing around Asheville since late 2024 after releasing a self-titled EP, which is currently available on streaming platforms.

Black Mountain College‚Äôs interdisciplinary and collaborative philosophy fostered groundbreaking time-based experiments across disciplines, significantly influencing performance, theater, film, music, dance, and visual art worldwide.¬†*Points in Space: Performance at Black Mountain College*¬†will feature¬†visual and time-based artworks that echo BMC‚Äôs innovative spirit from 1933 to 1957.¬†BMC was a nexus of avant-garde activity, fostering innovation through collaboration and experiential learning. The exhibition will highlight key events and figures, such as John Cage, Merce Cunningham, Lou Harrison, Roland Hayes, Ray Johnson, Hugo Kauder, Ursula Mamlok, Robert Rauschenberg, David Tudor, Alma Stone Williams, Stan Vanderbeek, and Stefan Wolpe, alongside movements like Bauhaus, Dada, and Fluxus. The exhibition will feature historical and contemporary works, interactive installations, performances, and immersive experiences that bring the past into conversation with the present.

*Points in Space*¬†aims to bridge the past and present, ensuring BMC‚Äôs interdisciplinary spirit continues to inspire new generations. Through performance-integrated exhibitions and public programs, the exhibition will foster a dynamic dialogue between historical and contemporary artistic practices, expanding the reach and relevance of BMC‚Äôs radical approach to art, education, and community engagement.

*Points in Space: Performance at Black Mountain College*¬†is organized by Jeff Arnal, curator, and Adolfo Alzuphar, curatorial assistant.

**AI Summary:** Featuring interactive stories, songs, and movement followed by a themed hands-on craft to boost early literacy.

### Description

11:00 am Family Storytime (birth ‚Äì 5 years) 11:30 am Craft Time Join us for stories, songs, movement and more as we celebrate and promote early and emergent literacy at the Transylvania County Library! Same theme and craft as Tuesday storytime. More About Early and Emergent Literacy Babies, toddlers, preschoolers, in all stages of development with their parents and caregivers are welcome to our morning of celebration. Children start to learn language from the day they are born. As they grow and develop, their speech and language skills become increasingly more complex. During early speech and language development, children learn skills that are important to the development of literacy (reading and writing). This stage, known as emergent literacy, begins at birth and continues through the preschool years. From birth, babies listen to language patterns in everyday speech, as well as in rhyming, chanting, and singing ‚Äì all of these play an important part in literacy development. As they develop, children see and interact with print in everyday situations. In everything from books and magazines to grocery lists, whether at home or in preschool, they are (and should be) encountering language in print well before they start elementary school. Parents can see their child‚Äôs growing appreciation and enjoyment of print as they begin to recognize words that rhyme, scribble with crayons, point out street signs and symbols, and name some letters of the alphabet. Gradually, children combine what they know about speaking and listening with what they know about print and become ready to learn to read and write. That‚Äôs what storytime at the library is all about!

Adults of all experience levels are welcome to attend. Meditation instruction will be given for beginners upon request.

The session begins promptly at 10:00 am. Please mute your audio during the guided meditation and talk.

Group Meditation Guidelines

- Arrive several minutes early. You are welcome to greet others before we start.
- Turn off your cell phones and other beeping devices.
- Sit in a comfortable position, either in your chair or cushions at home (preferably in a quiet room)
- Please mute yourself during guided meditation, and talk, and then unmute yourself to share during the discussion.
- Please remain still and do not carry your computer around, as it makes others dizzy.
- Thank you for helping us create this peaceful and safe refuge.

Meditating with others enriches and supports your practice - even online. We hope you will join us!

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. ### Description

You will be provided with your sanitized supplies, or feel free to bring your own colored pencils, markers, or other art supplies to express yourself during this Connection Practice Meeting.

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates. All connection practices are free of charge.

## Shut Up & Write!¬Æ - Downtown

**Date:** Tuesday, January 13, 2026 at 6:00 PM

**Location:** Sweets and Seats, 77, 81 Patton Ave,, Asheville, NC

**Organizer:** Shut Up & Write!¬Æ Western North Carolina

**Price:** Free

**Source:** MEETUP

**Tags:** Education, Community, writing group, focused sprints, creative writing, beginner friendly, cafe meetup

**Score:** 5/30 (Rarity: 1, Unique: 2, Magnitude: 2)
**Score Reason:** Weekly recurring event - happens every week.

**AI Summary:** Featuring structured 60-minute heads-down writing sprints with brief introductions for peer accountability and distraction-free focus.

### Description

Shut Up & Write!

**Here's how it works.** Show up at or before 6:00. At 6:00, we do some quick introductions. Afterward, for a full 60 minutes (I'll set a timer!) we are heads-down writing. Writing what? A novel? You bet. Some poetry? Sure. Song lyrics? Your resume? That report you need to get to your boss before 8 AM or you'll *need* *to write* that resume? All of the above and more. Just shut up and write.

Surrounding ourselves with other writers who are busy putting words onto page (physical or virtual) keeps us all accountable and focused.

When the timer goes off, we'll check-in with each other and see how it went. Afterward, feel free to stay to chat and get to know your fellow writers, or keep writing, or take off.

Socializing is optional and will happen after (or briefly before) the focused writing. This is a safe space to work on your craft. No one will read or critique your writing.

For more information about our events, visit [https://shutupwrite.com](https://shutupwrite.com).

**What to Expect**

* Roughly 15 minutes of introductions
* 60 minutes of focused writing (somebody set a timer)!
* Afterward, optional socializing

**Being late is okay:** Just show up and get settled, then check in with the host after the session. (Look for the person with the Shut Up & Write sign).

**What Should I Bring?**

* Whatever you need to be able to write!
* Earbuds/earplugs if you want to block ambient noise.

**Other Important Details:**

HOSTS: This is a multi-host event, so most of the time there will be a host present. If we are unlucky and no host can attend, please find each other and self-organize. Pay attention to the event chat and comments to see who is available.

WI-FI: Yes!

PARKING: Street parking in metered spots is free after 6pm. Closest municipal garages ($2/hour) are Wall St. & Coxe Street/Sears Alley.

The view of the world in Vajrayana is that innate wisdom and potential for awakening is always present. ### Description

A Connection Practice is a meeting to practice your skills in listening and connecting with others. No conversation topic is off limits. The only objective of the meeting is to feel a genuine sense of connection by the time it's over, and the only rule is that we promise to not give each other advice.

One seeker always facilitates the meeting (to guide the conversation, manage time, and introduce different exercises to help the group feel connected), and another always volunteers as Space Owl (to step aside with anyone who has a big emotional experience and needs 1-on-1 connection).

There is no hierarchy in Connection Practice meetings, and everyone is encouraged to share equally and freely, including the person who facilitates.

AMC is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization.

**There are moments in our lives, there are moments in a day, when we seem to see beyond the usual--become clairvoyant. We reach then into reality. Such are the moments of our greatest happiness. Such are the moments of our greatest vision....At such times there is a song going on within us, a song to which we listen. It fills us with surprise. We marvel at it. We would continue to hear it. But few are capable of holding themselves in the state of listening to their song. Intellectuality steps in and as the song within us is of the utmost sensitiveness, it retires in the presence of the cold, material intellect. It is aristocratic and will not associate itself with the commonplace--and we fall back and become our ordinary selves. Yet we live in the memory of these songs which in moments of intellectual inadvertence have been possible to us. ALL AGESPARTIALLY SEATED SHOW (guaranteed seating AND standing room only tickets are available at checkout) CHATHAM COUNTY LINE Launched a little more than twenty years ago in Raleigh, North Carolina, Chatham County Line built a devoted local following on the strength of their genre-bending live show-an intoxicating blend of bluegrass, folk, country, and rock and roll-before breaking out internationally with their 2003 self-titled debut. In the years to come, the band would go on to release eight more critically acclaimed studio albums, top the Billboard Bluegrass Chart four times, collaborate with the likes of Judy Collins, Sharon Van Etten, and Norwegian star Jonas Fjeld, earn two gold records in Norway (where they were also twice nominated for the Spellemannprisen, Norway's equivalent of a Grammy), and share bills with everyone from Guy Clark and Lyle Lovett to Steve Martin & Martin Short and The Avett Brothers. NPR hailed the group as "a bridge between bluegrass traditions and a fresh interpretation of those influences," while Uncut lauded their "powerful melodies and gorgeous harmonies," and Pitchfork dubbed their music "timeless." The band's latest release, Hiyo, marks the band's first release since the departure of their longtime banjo player and serves as something of a reintroduction to the roots stalwarts, complete with new sounds, new collaborators, and a whole new lease on life. Recorded at Asheville's Echo Mountain studio with co-producer/engineer Rachael Moore (Kacey Musgraves, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss), the collection finds the trio-Dave Wilson (lead singer/guitarist), John Teer (fiddle/mandolin) and Greg Readling (bass/pedal steel), embracing change at every turn, experimenting with fresh sonic palettes and innovative approaches to their core instrumentation. **Sensory Immersion Night**
Have you explored sensory Exploration for your nervous system?
Our senses have a beautiful way of grounding us into the present moment but this can take some work. Our sensory world can also become disconnected when our nervous system has stayed in pattern loops from high levels of stress and/or trauma.

This is essentially a disconnect of mind and body. The sensory information we receive from the outside world, drives movement patterns in the body. So, if we‚Äôre constantly perceiving the world as unsafe, we will move in that way.

**How do we begin to correct this?**
We start the practice of reintegrating the senses. Meditating can be challenging when we‚Äôve been in a heightened state, so exploring adding additional sensory input can help to get you out of attachment to your busy racing thoughts and into the feelings/sensations created in your body. The more you explore the five traditional senses more mindfully, the more you can perceive energy. The more energy you perceive, the more you feel connected to everything. Learning to express and move energy is vulnerable, but as the research shows, vulnerability is the key to personal freedom.

This evening will be all about tuning in and listening to your needs. This is a neurodivergent friendly space that honors consent and personal preferences.

mindful sensory exploration
stations to explore various sensory techniques
group meditation with added sensory input
Donation only/pay what you can

ALL AGES SEATED SHOW LIMITED NUMBER OF PREMIUM SEATING TICKETS AVAILABLE WILLIS ALAN RAMSEY Over 50 years after the release of his wildly influential self-titled album on Leon Russell's Shelter Records, Willis Alan Ramsey returns to touring. Ramsey's debut in 1972 earned scores of accolades from arti-sts ranging from The Allman Brothers to Lyle Lovett. The album was mined by many artists for their o_wn recordings including Jimmy Buffett's "The Ballad of Spider John", Jimmie Dale Gilmore's "Goodbye Old Missoula", Shawn Colvin's "Satin Sheets", Captain & Tennille's "Muskrat Candlelight/Love", Jerry Jeff Walker's "Northeast Texas Women", Waylon Jennings' "Satin Sheets", New Grass Revival's "Watermelon Man", and many more. Since that landmark first release, Ramsey has toured only occasionally, spending time instead with his family, honing his craft in Austin, Nashville and London, educating himself in the science of audio recording and composing new songs. His new material has received critical acclaim, including Lyle Lovett's recordings of "Sleepwalkin"', "North Dakota" and "That's Right (You're Not From Texas"), as well as Eric Clapton's recording of"Positively". Ramsey's infrequent personal appearances always gamer excitement among some of the top critics in the country as well as from his fellow artists: "His cozy, orderly, tiny-detail songs express a willful turnabout from hippie chaos, a visceral reaction particular to the early 1970's. His songs are sweet, emotionally guarded and often musically complex, fitting strains of melody together that seem as if they ought not connect, expertly using rhythmic displacement as the words and chords unspool .... Perfection is terrifying, and some of these songs felt spooky." - Ben Ratliff, The New York Times "You might have not seen him lately, but if you've listened to Shawn, Lyle or Jimmie Dale, you've heard him." - John T.
